messageBody:
Paige Gabhart scripsit:

> I agree as well. Unstandardized QS does not affect
> understandability. So if that is the case then it should not be a
> problem for people to write as they speak. I am a U.S. citizen, and
> in the mid 70s I corresponded with a man in New Zealand in QS. I
> had no difficulty in understanding his QS. I think the drive toward
> standardizing QS arises out of the same human desire for uniformity
> that sent TO down the wrong path centuries ago.

Historically, the pressure to standardize orthographies comes from publishers,
who need to know the difference between a typo they should correct and a mere
variant spelling they must preserve. By not having variant spellings, the
distinction is more obvious. I know of no orthography generally used for
published works that is not standardized.

--
